author: Bloomberg.com
title: Asian Stocks Set to Track Draghi Surge While Nasdaq Futures Jump
text:
The October stock rally is back, thanks to some handy comments on stimulus from Mario Draghi and better-than-expected earnings U.S. technology company earnings.
Asian index futures signaled gains from Japan to Hong Kong, and Australian equities jumped Friday after Draghi said the European Central Bank will consider bolstering its bond-buying program before the end of 2015, sparking a surge in European and U.S. stocks. Nasdaq 100 Index futures were about 1.6 percent above the gauge’s closing level after shares of Google parent Alphabet Inc. and Amazon.com Inc. jumped more than 10 percent in extended trading. The euro sank to a two-month low.
“Mario Draghi and his elves at the ECB practically confirmed there will be an early Christmas present,” Evan Lucas, a market strategist in Melbourne at IG Ltd., said in an e-mail to clients. “In short, all options are on the table for the ECB, also meaning the Bank of Japan and the Fed are now live events as well.”
The ECB is the latest central bank to switch to a more preservative tone on stimulus, with its willingness to bolster support for the euro-area economy a shot in the arm for risk assets that have benefited from the wave of global monetary easing. With banks and retailers posting more mixed results this season, the results from Google to Amazon, which reported a surprise profit, as well as Microsoft Corp., bolstered optimism over the outlook for U.S. equities. Stocks in New York returned Thursday to their trading range from before China’s shock yuan devaluation in August. A gauge of Japanese manufacturing is due Friday, along with Chinese house prices.
Stocks
The S&P/ASX 200 Index climbed 1.9 percent by 10:52 a.m. in Sydney, rising for a third day to be on track for a 1.8 percent advance in the week. New Zealand’s S&P/NZX 50 Index, the first major stock gauge to start trading each day in the Asian region rose for an 11th day in its longest rally since November.
Futures on the Nasdaq 100 traded at 4,576.25, compared with 4,492.50 at 4 p.m. Thursday in New York and the index’s closing level of 4,503.22. Shares of Alphabet, the new holding company that encompasses Google, soared as much as 13 percent after hours as an increase in advertising sales and restrained spending underpinned the third-quarter results. Amazon reported a 17 cents-a-share profit, amid analysts’ expectations for a loss of 13 cents. Microsoft rallied 7.9 percent in extended trade on above-estimate earnings.
Standard & Poor’s 500 Index futures rose 0.3 percent following a 1.7 percent surge in the U.S. benchmark. Thursday’s gain brought the S&P 500’s rebound from an August trough to 9.9 percent and the gauge is back within a range that stretched from about 2,040 to its all-time high of 2,130.82. It’s now down 0.3 percent in 2015.
In Japan, traders were preparing for significant gains, with futures on the Nikkei 225 Stock Average bid up by 2.4 percent in the Osaka pre-market, to 18,890. Yen-denominated contracts on the gauge climbed 0.3 percent in Chicago to 18,915, after jumping 2.3 percent in the previous session.
Futures on Hong Kong’s Hang Seng Index increased 1.3 percent in most recent trading, while those on the Hang Seng China Enterprises Index, which tracks mainland equities listed in the city, rallied 1.6 percent. FTSE China A50 Index futures in Singapore were up 1.3 percent following a 1.5 percent climb in the Shanghai Composite Index Thursday. Shanghai shares are down 0.7 percent this week amid concern the recent rally wasn’t warranted.
Kospi index futures in Seoul climbed 0.9 percent before a report showed gross domestic product in South Korea expanded 2.6 percent last quarter from a year earlier, exceeding the 2.4 percent median of economists’ estimates. One-month non-deliverable forwards on the Korean won strengthened 0.6 percent.
While India returns from a holiday Friday, markets in Thailand are shut. Malaysia and Singapore update on consumer prices, while Taiwan reports industrial output.
